pages.title: 10 Signs You've Spent Too Long in Academia (A Satirist's Guide)
pages.content:
You know you&rsquo;ve spent too long in academia when the phrase &ldquo;let&rsquo;s table this discussion&rdquo; fills you with both rage and resignation. Here are ten signs that the ivory tower has become less of a workplace and more of a lifestyle.
1. You Have Opinions About Fonts Not just &ldquo;Comic Sans is unprofessional&rdquo; opinions. We&rsquo;re talking &ldquo;I can&rsquo;t take this email seriously because they used Calibri instead of Times New Roman, and everyone knows Calibri is for …

pages.title: The Ultimate Guide to Writing Satire That Actually Works
pages.content:
Writing satire is like performing surgery with a rubber chicken—you need precision, timing, and the willingness to accept that some people just won&rsquo;t get it.
After years of writing satirical comedy (and receiving approximately 847 concerned emails from people who took my jokes literally), I&rsquo;ve developed what I humbly call &ldquo;The Prof Y Not Method&rdquo; of satire writing. Today, I&rsquo;m sharing it with you.
What Satire Actually Is (And Isn&rsquo;t) Let&rsquo;s clear something …

pages.title: How to Market Your Humor Book on Amazon KDP (Without Losing Your Mind)
pages.content:
Marketing a humor book on Amazon is like trying to explain a joke in an elevator pitch—you&rsquo;ve got approximately 7 seconds before someone&rsquo;s attention wanders to another of the 3 million books published this year.
Having navigated the peculiar waters of KDP marketing for comedy books, I&rsquo;m here to share what works, what doesn&rsquo;t, and what will make you question your career choices.
Understanding the Amazon Algorithm (Sort Of) Let me be honest: nobody fully understands …

pages.title: Why This Professor Finally Lost It (A Memoir Preview)
pages.content:
The following is an exclusive preview of my upcoming satirical memoir. Names have been changed to protect the guilty.
Chapter 1: The Day the Projector Won It was 8:47 AM on a Tuesday when I lost the ability to pretend academia made sense.
The projector—that ancient demon of failed presentations everywhere—had decided that today, of all days, would be the moment it would showcase every color except the ones in my PowerPoint. The students watched my carefully crafted slides transform into what …

About This Book Prof or not, here I come! is the satirical comedy that finally says what every academic has been thinking but was too afraid to put in their tenure portfolio.
Follow our unnamed narrator—a professor of indeterminate discipline at a university of questionable reputation—as they navigate the treacherous waters of:
Faculty meetings that could have been emails (which could have been nothing) Committee assignments that multiply like academic rabbits Student emails that begin with …
